description: From an Australian Aboriginal language; cf. Wulna nākā (“dress, covering”)

examples: Boys and many of the men wear the naga, akin to bathing trunks  […]

description: Borrowed from Sanskrit नाग (nāga, “serpent, snake”). Doublet of snake.

entries.meaning: (Indian mythology) A member of a class of semi-divine creatures, often taking the form of a very large snake and associated with water.
examples: The five-coned towers form a quincunx, and their flanks are scooped into niches in each of which has been placed a smiling buddha shaded by a nine-headed naga like a big palm fan.
